hints_html: A possible solution involves applying once the substitution rule and twice integration by parts.
hints_latex:
A possible solution involves applying once the substitution rule and
twice integration by parts.
hints_raw: A possible solution involves applying once the substitution rule and twice integration by parts.
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
The computation of the given integral involves several steps.

Step 1. In the first step we apply the substitution rule with \(u = \ln(x)\). This implies \(du/dx = 1/x\) and in particular \(dx = x du\). Hence,

\[\begin{aligned} \int \cos(\ln(x)) \, dx = \int \cos(u)\cdot x \, du\end{aligned}\]

We have to rewrite \(x\) in terms of \(u\). This can be done by exponentiating the substitution equation

\[\begin{aligned} e^u = x.\end{aligned}\]

We arrive at

\[\begin{aligned} \int \cos(u)\cdot x \, du = \int \cos(u)e^u \, du\end{aligned}\]

Step 2. We apply integration by parts with \(f(u) = \cos(u)\) and \(g'(u) = e^u\):

\[\begin{aligned} \int \cos(u)e^u \, du = \cos(u)e^u + \int \sin(u)e^u \, du\end{aligned}\]

Integration by parts onto the integral in the right-hand side with \(f(u)=\sin(u)\) and \(g'(u)=e^u\) yields

\[\begin{aligned} \int \sin(u)e^u \, du = \sin(u)e^u - \int \cos(u)e^u \, du\end{aligned}\]

Step 3. Step 1 and Step 2 together results in the equation

\[\begin{aligned} \int \cos(u)e^u \, du &= \cos(u)e^u + \int \sin(u)e^u \, du \\ &= \cos(u)e^u + \sin(u)e^u - \int \cos(u)e^u \, du\end{aligned}\]

Step 4. We bring the integral on the right-hand side of the equation over to the left-hand side:

\[\begin{aligned} 2\int\cos(u)e^u \, du = \cos(u)e^u + \sin(u)e^u = e^u(\sin(u) + \cos(u))\end{aligned}\]

Finally, we divide the equation by 2:

\[\begin{aligned} \int\cos(u)e^u \, du = \frac{e^u}{2}(\sin(u) + \cos(u)) + C\end{aligned}\]

where \(C\) is an arbitrary constant

Step 5. The last step is to rewrite our results in terms of \(x\). Remember, that our very first step was the substitution \(u = \ln(x)\). Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} \int \cos(\ln(x)) \, dx &= \int \cos(u)e^u \, du \\ &= \frac{e^u}{2}(\sin(u) + \cos(u)) + C \\ &= \frac{x}{2}(\sin(\ln(x)) + \cos(\ln(x))) + C\end{aligned}\]

where we used \(e^u = x\).
sols_raw:
The computation of the given integral involves several steps.

'''Step 1.''' In the first step we apply the substitution rule with <math>u = \ln(x)</math>. This implies <math>du/dx = 1/x</math> and in particular <math>dx = x du</math>. Hence,

:<math>\int \cos(\ln(x)) \, dx = \int \cos(u)\cdot x \, du</math>

We have to rewrite <math>x</math> in terms of <math>u</math>. This can be done by exponentiating the substitution equation: <math>e^u = x</math>. We arrive at

:<math>\int \cos(u)\cdot x \, du = \int \cos(u)e^u \, du</math>

'''Step 2.''' We apply integration by parts with <math>f(u) = \cos(u)</math> and <math>g'(u) = e^u</math>:

:<math>\int \cos(u)e^u \, du = \cos(u)e^u + \int \sin(u)e^u \, du</math>

Integration by parts onto the integral in the right-hand side with <math>f(u)=\sin(u)</math> and <math>g'(u)=e^u</math> yields

:<math>\int \sin(u)e^u \, du = \sin(u)e^u - \int \cos(u)e^u \, du</math>

'''Step 3.''' Step 1 and Step 2 together results in the equation

:<math>
\begin{align}
\int \cos(u)e^u \, du &= \cos(u)e^u + \int \sin(u)e^u \, du \\
&= \cos(u)e^u + \sin(u)e^u - \int \cos(u)e^u \, du
\end{align}
</math>

'''Step 4.''' We bring the integral on the right-hand side of the equation over to the left-hand side:

:<math>2\int\cos(u)e^u \, du =  \cos(u)e^u + \sin(u)e^u = e^u(\sin(u) + \cos(u))</math>

Finally, we divide the equation by 2:

:<math>
\int\cos(u)e^u \, du = \frac{e^u}{2}(\sin(u) + \cos(u)) + C
</math>

where <math>C</math> is an arbitrary constant

'''Step 5.''' The last step is to rewrite our results in terms of <math>x</math>. Remember, that our very first step was the substitution <math>u = \ln(x)</math>. Therefore

:<math>
\begin{align}
\int \cos(\ln(x)) \, dx &= \int \cos(u)e^u \, du \\
 &= \frac{e^u}{2}(\sin(u) + \cos(u)) + C \\
&= \frac{x}{2}(\sin(\ln(x)) + \cos(\ln(x))) + C
\end{align}
</math>

where we used <math>e^u = x</math>.
statement_html:
The question in the exam asks you to determine the following indefinite integral:
\(\int \cos(\ln(x)) \, \text{d}x\)
statement_latex:
The question in the exam asks you to determine the following indefinite
integral:\\$\int \cos(\ln(x)) \, \text{d}x$
statement_raw:
The question in the exam asks you to determine the following indefinite integral:<br>
<math>\int \cos(\ln(x)) \, \text{d}x</math>
